Tailoring the photoluminescence of atomically precise nanoclusters
Xi Kang ab and Manzhou Zhu *ab
Due to their atomically precise structures and intriguing chemical/physical properties, metal
nanoclusters are an emerging class of modular nanomaterials. Photo-luminescence (PL) is one of their
most fascinating properties, due to the plethora of promising PL-based applications, such as chemical
sensing, bio-imaging, cell labeling, phototherapy, drug delivery, and so on. However, the PL of most
current nanoclusters is still unsatisfactory—the PL quantum yield (QY) is relatively low (generally lower
than 20%), the emission lifetimes are generally in the nanosecond range, and the emitted color is always
red (emission wavelengths of above 630 nm). To address these shortcomings, several strategies have been
adopted, and are reviewed herein: capped-ligand engineering, metallic kernel alloying, aggregation-induced
emission, self-assembly of nanocluster building blocks into cluster-based networks, and adjustments on
external environment factors. We further review promising applications of these fluorescent nanoclusters,
with particular focus on their potential to impact the fields of chemical sensing, bio-imaging, and bio-labeling.
Finally, scope for improvements and future perspectives of these novel nanomaterials are highlighted as well.
Our intended audience is the broader scientific community interested in the fluorescence of metal
nanoclusters, and our review hopefully opens up new horizons for these scientists to manipulate PL
properties of nanoclusters. This review is based on publications available up to December 2018.

Additionally, the atomically precise nature of their structures enables elucidation of structure–property relationships, which is essential if nanoclusters with enhanced performances are to be rationally designed.52–63
Photo-luminescence (PL) is amongst the most intriguing and fascinating characteristics of these nanomaterials. Compared to organic fluorophores or semiconductor quantum dots (QDs), PL nanoclusters generally exhibit superior photo-stability and biocompatibility, and reduced toxicity; and therefore hold great promise for use in chemical sensing, cell labeling, bio-imaging, phototherapy, and drug delivery.4,20,22,64–68 Recent breakthroughs in the design and application of fluorescent nanoclusters have been reported in the fields of chemical sensing and biology.4,64–76
In contrast to conventional PL materials, such as fluorescent organic molecules,77–80 QDs,81–84 carbon nanodots,85–87 and lanthanide nanoparticles,88,89 the quantum yield (QY) of metal nanoclusters is relatively low. Furthermore, the fraction of metal nanoclusters that fluoresce is also low; and the mechanistic origins of PL are still mysterious. In addition, protocols to enable the rapid, consistent preparation of fluorescent nanoclusters with atomically-precise structures and predictable fluorescent properties are highly desirable, as precise control over the factors of metallic composition and well-defined surface chemistry is not only critical to the firm understanding of the structure– fluorescence correlation, but also informs the design and preparation of new nanoclusters with enhanced PL QY and adjustable emission wavelength. Indeed, not until the PL of nanoclusters can be reliably tailored in rapid, reproducible, and atomically precise ways will their advantages and potentials as nanomaterials be realized. To date, although a wide variety of fluorescent nanoclusters have been prepared, the PL QYs of most of them are lower than 20%, and the emission wavelengths mostly center in the red region; these limitations have impeded their applications. Recent efforts have sought to tailor the fluorescent properties of the nanoclusters, including PL intensity and emission wavelength, the two basic characteristics of fluorescence.20,90,91
The preparation, characterization, structural determination, properties, and applications of nanoclusters have been previously reviewed.1–3,9–12,92–96 In particular, the Jin group reviewed the principles that permit mono-disperse preparations, atomically precise structures, and physical/chemical properties of metal nanoclusters (mainly on Au nanoclusters);1 and Pradeep and co-workers summarized the measurements and applications of nanoclusters, and meticulously summarized Ag-based nanoclusters.2 However, their reviews focused primarily on the structures, characterizations, and structure–property correlations of metal nanoclusters, and not their fluorescent properties. Also, although several other reviews focusing on the development of fluorescent nanoclusters have been recently published, they generally either (i) summarize the structures and emissions of luminescent nanoclusters (especially hydrophilic nanoclusters) with atomically precise structures;20,21,97 or (ii) review their applications (chemical sensing, bio-labelling, bio-imaging, and so on).67–74 Reviews of the former category mainly focus on the atomically precise structures of
these fluorescent nanoclusters; however, their discussions and summaries upon the PL controlling strategies are inadequate. Reviews on the latter mainly focus on the PL performance of hydrophilic nanoclusters, which are much more suitable for biological applications than hydrophobic ones; however, the imprecise structures of the water-soluble nanoclusters impede a thorough understanding of the relationships between structures and fluorescent properties, and therefore their rational design based on specific, desirable PL characteristics is difficult. In this context, there is an urgent need for a new review focused upon strategies that can be used to enhance the fluorescence intensity of nanoclusters and adjust the emission wavelength; especially given the explosive rate of the development of this field. Herein, we intend to highlight the recent and relevant advances through judicious selection of recent articles.
This review is divided into five sections: (1) engineering of the peripheral ligands on the nanocluster surface (Scheme 1a); (2) modifying the kernel size or alloying the kernel with heterometals (Scheme 1b); (3) aggregation-induced emission (AIE, Scheme 1c); (4) self-assembly of the nanocluster building blocks into cluster-based networks (Scheme 1d); (5) regulation of external environment factors. In addition, some structure–PL relationships are disclosed; and the applications of nanoclusters in the fields of chemical sensing, cell imaging and bio-labeling are also summarized. Finally, the outlook for these fluorescent nanoclusters is presented, with reference to both ongoing fundamental research and potential applications. Above all, the goal of this review is to provide researchers attempting to design fluorescent nanoclusters with a synthetic toolbox of techniques that will help them improve PL QYs and adjust emission wavelengths of nanoclusters.

sections.heading: 2 PL control through engineering of the peripheral ligands
sections.text:
This section will focus on the effect of the peripheral ligands on nanocluster PL intensities and emission wavelengths. The metallic kernel and peripheral ligand(s) (which cap the metallic kernel) are the two main constituents of a metal nanocluster. The role of the ligand was long overlooked, because the longchain HS-PhC2H4, glutathione (HS-G), and HS-CnH2n+1 ligands behaved similarly in synthesizing gold nanoclusters with the same configuration (i.e., Au25(S-PhC2H4)18, Au25(S-CnH2n+1)18 and Au25(SG)18 nanoclusters with the same Au13 kernel@ Au12(SR)18 shell configuration).
60 However, more recently, the electronic and steric characteristics of the peripheral ligands have been demonstrated to profoundly influence both the electronic/geometric structures of the nanoclusters and their optical performance.98–101 The LMCT process (ligand-to-metal charge transfer) is normally responsible for the PL of the fluorescent nanoclusters, and researchers have successfully regulated the PL performance of nanoclusters through controlling the electron donating capability of the peripheral ligands.102,103 Also, since energy loss by non-radiative transition (which is greatly influenced by intramolecular vibrations) affects energy release

Ligand exchange is therefore a special and versatile strategy for tuning the PL intensity and wavelength. The peripheral ligands of a nanocluster can be partially or completely replaced by the foreign ligands without perturbation of the constituent metal atoms of the nanocluster framework. Also, the nanocluster framework can be transformed in certain chemical environments (Scheme 1a). This section will focus on the effect of ligands on fluorescent nanoclusters in terms of PL intensities and emission wavelengths.
2.1 PL regulation via ligand engineering with preservation of the nanocluster structure
The ability to modify the peripheral ligands of a specific nanocluster with conservation of the template (i.e., with preservation of the nanocluster metallic kernel) enables the relationship between ligand environments and nanocluster properties to be
elucidated, which is of great importance for tuning nanocluster performance and enhancing their practical utility. Early studies in this field used an Au25 nanocluster as a template to research the effect on fluorescence,102,103 and insights into the mechanism of the fluorescence of these nanoclusters were obtained. Based on these results, several ligand engineering strategies for regulating PL intensities and emission wavelengths of fluorescent nanoclusters were developed.102,103
Jin and co-workers explored how the PL intensity of a series of Au25(SR)18 nanoclusters depended on the identity of the protecting ligands.103 They showed that the PL intensity increased with increasing charge donating capability of ligands: Au25(SC2H4Ph)18 4 Au25(SC12H25)18 4 Au25(SC6H13)18 (all three of these Au25 nanoclusters are in the ‘‘1 ’’ charge state). The surface ligands were hypothesized to influence the PL intensity in two ways: (i) charge transfer from the ligands to the metal nanocluster kernel (i.e., LMCT) through the Au–S interactions; (ii) direct donation of delocalized electrons from electron-rich atoms (or groups) on the ligands to the metallic kernel.

By substituting the thiolate capping ligands with selenolate, Song et al. prepared an [Au25(SePh)18]
1 nanocluster,104 which was found to exhibit a feeble PL at about 1100 nm, much less intense than the PL of the [Au25(SCH2CH2Ph)18]
1 nanocluster. The weakened fluorescence is probably due to the less pronounced charge transfer from the peripheral ligand to the metallic kernel of the Se–Au interactions relative to the S–Au interactions.104
Zhu and co-workers prepared an Au25 nanocluster stabilized by the 2-(naphthalen-2-yl)ethanethiolate (NAPS) ligands, the fluorescent intensity of which was 6.5 fold higher than that of the [Au25(SCH2CH2Ph)18] 1 nanocluster.105 The PL of [Au25(NAPS)18] 1 consisted of two bands at 740 nm and 680 nm, compared with the single band at 740 nm of Au25(S-C2H4Ph)18. The two bands of Au25(NAPS)18 were hypothesized to originate from the vibration of the naphthalen-2-yl group—the energy spacing of B1200 cm 1 being in approximate correspondence to the gap between its excited
states; and the higher energy emission (680 nm) from the surface ligands—the wavelength of this emission being too low to be explained by the metallic kernel quantization effect.105
Water-soluble thiolate-protected Au25 nanoclusters have been known to exhibit stronger luminescence than their organicsoluble counterparts, but their PL is still amenable to tuning through modification of their ligands.106–109 Shibu et al. partially exchanged the capped ligands of the Au25(SG)18 nanocluster (SG represents glutathione) with three different ligands (3-mercapto2-butanol (MB), N-acetyl-glutathione (NAGSH) and N-formylglutathione (NFGSH)) and compared the emissions of the ligandexchanged Au25(SG)18 x(SR)x nanoclusters.
107 The PL spectra (excitation and emission) of Au25–SGAN and Au25–SGFN were almost the same as those of the Au25(SG)18 nanocluster. However, the PL spectra of the MB-substituted products Au25(MB)x(SG)18 x were different, having a B20 nm blue-shift in the excitation spectra and a B30 nm blue-shift in the emission spectra, relative to the initial Au25(SG)18 nanocluster.

In addition to the spherical Au25 nanoclusters, the emissions of other fluorescent nanoclusters have also been examined. Park and Lee synthesized a batch of rod-like Au25 (or so-called bi-icosahedral Au25) nanoclusters protected by different thiols (e.g., HSCH2CH2Ph, HSC4–12H7–23, 11-mercaptoundecanoic acid and 11- mercapto-1-undecanol).110 All bi-icosahedral [Au25(PPh3)10(SR)5Cl2] 2+ nanoclusters exhibited similar excitation and emission spectra, with the maximum emission at about 825 nm (except for the PL spectrum of SCH2CH2Ph stabilized bi-icosahedral Au25 that displayed an additional shoulder band at about 780 nm). The PL intensity of the SCH2CH2Ph protected rod-like Au25 was higher than that of any other bi-icosahedral Au25 nanoclusters. The ligand-dependent luminescence originated from differences in the electron donating capabilities of the ligands, which further affected the degree of charge transfer (LMCT) from the surface ligands to the Au metallic kernel.110
Wu and co-workers compared the PL intensities of Au24 nanoclusters protected by different ligands,111,112 and found that Au24(SePh)20 o Au24(SC2H4Ph)20 o Au24(SCH2Ph)20 o Au24(SCH2C6H4 tBu)20. 112 Given that all of these Au24 nanoclusters comprised an Au8 kernel and two pairs of Au4(SR)5 motifs, the observed differences in PL intensity and emission wavelength were thought to arise from differences in the degree of electron-transfer from the capped ligand to the kernel moiety through the Au–S and Au–Se interactions. The PL intensity of Au24(SR)20 was also noted to be significantly higher than those of other thiolated gold nanoclusters such as Au20(SR)16, Au25(SR)18, Au28(SR)20, Au38(SR)24, Au44(SR)28 and Au52(SR)32; an observation attributed to two structural features of Au24(SR)20: (i) two pairs of interlocked Au4(SR)5 staple motifs that reduced the vibration loss of the whole structure; (ii) interactions between the Au8 kernel and the staple motifs that enhanced electron transfer from the ligand to the kernel.112
Konishi and co-workers evaluated the PL emission wavelength of a series of [Au8(DPPP)4X2]
2+ nanoclusters (where DPPP represents Ph2P(CH2)3PPh2 and X represents SR), capped with different ligands.113 When the terminal X was SPh, S(2-Py), S(3-Py), S(4-Py) or SC6H4(4-NO2), the emission wavelengths centered at 621, 604, 612, 609 or 623 nm, respectively. For comparison, the Cl terminal (i.e., X = Cl) blue-shifted the emission to 600 nm. Besides, the CRCPh terminal (i.e., XQCRCPh) further blue-shifted the emission to 580 nm. Interestingly, the addition of MeSO3H induced further shifts of 25 nm (for X = S(2-Py)), 6 nm (for X = S(3-Py)), and 16 nm (for X = S(4-Py)) and a minimum of 3-fold enhancement of PL intensity.113
Surface engineering of Au36(TBBT)24 (where TBBT = SPhp-tBu) nanoclusters for PL enhancement has been performed by Kim and co-workers,114 who undertook partial substitution of the TBBT ligands on Au36 with 4-fluorothiophenol (FBT), 4-bromobenzenethiol (BBT), and cyclopentanethiol (CPT) ligands, with preservation of the Au36 metallic kernel.
114 ESI-MS (electrospray ionization mass spectrometry) results demonstrated that up to 14 (or 12) FBT (or BBT) ligands could be exchanged onto the nanocluster surface. The PL intensities of the obtained
Au36 nanoclusters were found to be directly proportional to the electronegativity of the peripheral ligands, reflecting the influence of ligand electron-donating ability on PL intensity. Ligand electron donating capability was also found to correlate with nanocluster fluorescence lifetime.114
On the basis of an Ag62 nanocluster template, the ligand effect on PL has been investigated.115–117 The Wang group previously reported a highly luminescent Ag quantum dot with a chemical formula of [Ag62S13(StBu)32] 4+ (Ag-QDs),115 in which no free valence electrons had been found. These Ag-QDs emitted bright-red light in the solid state with maximum emission at 621 nm, but at 613 nm when the Ag-QDs were in solution (Fig. 2b, bottom-left).115 Jin et al. reported the synthesis and crystal structure of the Ag62 nanocluster formulated as [Ag62S12(StBu)32] 2+ (Ag-NCs), which can be regarded as an Ag-QD lacking the innermost S ligand.116 [Ag62S12(StBu)32] 2+ was found to contain a complete Ag14 FCC (face center cubic) kernel, in contrast to the irregular Ag14S FCC kernel in the Ag62 quantum dot.115,116 The PL intensity of Ag-NCs was much weaker than that of the Ag-QDs. Comparison of the femtosecond transient absorption spectroscopies of these two compounds demonstrated that this was due to fluorescence quenching caused by free valence electrons in Ag-NCs, which dramatically change the LMCT process (S 3p - Ag 5s).116 Of note, the Ag-QDs could be electrochemically reduced into the Ag-NCs, via an intermediate compound formulated as [Ag62S13(StBu)32] 2+ (Ag-inter), wherein the Ag62 nanocluster template remained unchanged (Fig. 2b).117 The PL intensity of the Ag-inter displayed a 2-fold enhancement relative to Ag-NCs, though it was still far below the intensity of Ag-QDs (Fig. 2b, bottom-right). Evolutionassociated transient absorptions of Ag-QDs, Ag-NCs, and Ag-inter suggested that the LMCT process was absent for Ag-NCs and Ag-inter, resulting in fluorescence quenching.117
The Liu group prepared the homo-silver [Ag20{S2P(OiPr)2}12] (Ag20–S for short) and [Ag21{S2P(OiPr)2}12](PF6) (Ag21–S for short) nanoclusters, which exhibited emissions in the near-IR region at 921 nm and 950 nm, respectively.118,119 Ligand-exchange of these two nanoclusters with Se-donor ligands gave [Ag20{Se2P(OiPr)2}12] (Ag20–Se) and [Ag21{Se2P(OEt)2}12](PF6) (Ag21–Se), which were found to have similar geometric structures but different PL–Ag20–S emitted at 921 nm vs. 720 nm for Ag20–Se; and Ag21–S emitted at 950 nm vs. 754 nm for Ag21–Se. 120
PL intensities can also be increased by strengthening the degree of LMCT/electron delocalization by ligand functionalization. Li et al. obtained a homo-silver Ag20 nanocluster co-stabilized by CO, StBu, NO3 and DMF ligands with a chemical formula of Ag20(CO3)1(S tBu)10(NO3)8(DMF)6. 121 It was found that the NO3 ligands could be easily substituted by carboxylic ligands with conservation of the inner core; the authors prepared a series of functional carboxylic or amino acid ligand co-stabilized Ag20 nanoclusters, which displayed novel chemical/physical properties such as fluorescence, electrochemical activity, and chirality.121 Specifically, the C12H6O2NCH2COO stabilized Ag20 nanocluster showed a green emission around 513 nm with a high PL QY of 6.36% at room temperature, in striking contrast to the non-luminescent Ag20 nanoclusters protected by NO3 or other

Enhancement of the steric hindrance (or rigidity) of the peripheral ligands (with preservation of the nanocluster template) can restrict the intramolecular rotation of a nanocluster, which in turn should improve PL efficiency. Zhu and co-workers investigated the relationship between the rigidity of peripheral thiol ligands and the PL intensity of Au2Cu6 nanoclusters.
122 The use of highly rigid peripheral ligands (S-Adm, 1-adamantanethiol) resulted in an Au2Cu6(S-Adm)6(PPh3)2 nanocluster with a high PL QY of 11.7%; in contrast, an Au2Cu6(TBM)6(PPh3)2 nanocluster capped with less rigid TBM (tert-butyl-mercaptan) had a lower PL QY of 8.0%.122
In follow-up work, the fluorescent intensity of Au2Cu6 nanoclusters capped with highly rigid S-Adm ligands was further increased through engineering the phosphine ligands.123 DFT (density functional theory) calculations indicated that the fluorescence corresponded to an electronic transition from the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) to the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO), and was mainly caused by charge transfer between the aromatic groups on phosphine ligands and the copper atoms in the metallic kernel; that is, the PL originated from LMCT.122,123 Inspired by this, the PL of Au2Cu6 nanoclusters has been precisely engineered by functionalizing the aromatic groups on the phosphine ligands with electron-donating groups (EDGs) or electron-withdrawing substituents (EWGs).123 As shown in Fig. 3, the PL intensity has been significantly enhanced from the Au2Cu6 nanocluster with P(Ph-F)3 ligands (QY of 5.7%) to that with PPh3 (QY of 12.2%) and P(Ph-OMe)3 ligands (QY of 17.7%). In addition, the PL emission of Au2Cu6 protected by P(Ph-OMe)3 (656 nm) showed slight red-shifts (B10 nm) compared to that of Au2Cu6 protected by P(Ph-F)3 (667 nm), which was similar to the trends seen in their UV-vis spectra.123

Using time-dependent density functional theory (TD-DFT) methods, Weerawardene and Aikens investigated the PL origin of Au25(SR)18 nanoclusters. 124 They found that the value of Stokes shift in the corresponding Au25(SR)18 nanocluster was proportional to the length of the carbon chain in the thiol ligand. Specifically, Stokes shifts of 0.49, 0.58, 0.56, and 0.68 eV were observed for [Au25(SR)18]
(R = H, CH3, CH2CH3, CH2CH2CH3) nanoclusters, respectively. 124 Through theoretical calculations, nuclear relaxation (involved in the excited-state nuclear relaxation) was proposed to be responsible for the vibrational frequencies in the 75–80 cm 1 range, which was in excellent agreement with the vibrations observed in time-resolved spectroscopy experiments. Furthermore, excited states at around 0.8, 1.15, and 1.25 eV in DFT calculation were responsible for emissions experimentally observed in the 1.15–1.55 eV range. Finally, the excited states of Au25(SR)18 nanoclusters were found to arise primarily from the core-based orbitals, and neither charge-transfer states nor other ‘‘semi-ring’’ or ligand-based states were implicated.124
The combination of precise nanoclusters with functional compounds generates highly oriented hybrid nanomaterials,
wherein the nanocluster template remains unchanged but the introduced compounds are anchored by the peripheral ligands of the nanoclusters.103,125–127 Such hybrid nanomaterials may exhibit novel properties, which are distinct from those of both nanoclusters and functioned compounds from which the hybrid nanomaterials derive.126,127 Wu and Jin introduced a long-chain peptide nucleic acid onto the Au25(SG)18 surface, in which the PL intensity exhibited a 2-fold enhancement owing to the enforced LMCT process.103 Wang and coworkers reported a thiol-stabilized Au11 nanocluster, which exhibited strong blue fluorescence (PL QY of 8.6%) upon encapsulating both 3-mercaptopropionic acid and tetraoctylammonium bromide.126 Of note, this carboxylic-acid-terminated thiolated Au11 was radically different from other Au11 nanoclusters capped with phosphine ligands in terms of the properties and structures.128–131 Lee and co-workers conjugated aminofluorescein (AF) on the as-prepared Au22 nanoclusters; the resulting, hybrid Au22–AF nanoclusters functioned as highly sensitive pH probes, wherein the PL intensity was found to vary by 160-fold with a change in pH in the range of 4.3–7.8.127

Such transformations induced by the ligand-exchange processes constitute an exciting opportunity for regulating nanocluster properties such as fluorescence.132–139 Three effects of ligands on nanocluster structures have been identified: (i) the bulkiness of the a-carbon on the capped ligand (e.g., bi-icosahedral Au38(S-C2H4Ph)24 can be converted to tetrahedral Au36(SPh-p-
tBu)24 via ligand-exchanging the less rigid S-C2H4Ph ligands into more rigid SPh-ptBu ligands);140,141 (ii) the structural hindrance of the rigid backbone of the capped ligand (e.g., the size of a series of atomically precise Au nanoclusters Au130(p-MBT)50, Au104(m-MBT)41, and Au40(o-MBT)24 was determined by the para-, meta-, or ortho-nature of the methylbenzenethiol ligands);99 (iii) the electron donating ability of the para-position groups in the benzene rings of thiol ligands (e.g., 4-methylbenzenethiol results in Au130(p-MBT)50, whereas 4-tert-butylbenzenethiol gives Au133(p-TBBT)52).
142,143 Besides, it is generally accepted that the structure of a nanocluster (also for other nanomaterials) determines its physical–chemical properties, such as optical absorption and emission.144–152 In this context, ligand effects significantly influence nanocluster PL by influencing nanocluster structures. In this section, studies related to PL regulation via ligand engineering with transformation of the nanocluster structure are highlighted.
In 2017, Kang et al. reported the transformation of the Pt1Ag24(SR)18 nanocluster from an icosahedron to a FCC Pt1Ag28(SAdm)18(PPh3)4 nanocluster, induced by ligand-exchange (Fig. 4a). 153
The resulting Pt1Ag28 exhibited remarkably enhanced PL intensity (QY = 4.9%, emission centered at 672 nm) compared to the starting Pt1Ag24 nanocluster (QY = 0.1%, emission centered at 728 nm). This nearly 50-fold improvement in fluorescence intensity was rationalized via analyses of electronic dynamics, which demonstrated that it originated from the suppressed phonon emission and other non-radiative pathways within the tetrahedral construction of the Pt1Ag28 nanocluster.
153 Of note, the Pt1Ag12 metallic kernel in this ligand-exchanged Pt1Ag28 nanocluster adopted a distorted FCC configuration.153
Compared with the control of the PL intensity, control of the emission wavelengths of nanoclusters is more difficult. The color emitted by most luminescent nanoclusters is red (that is, emission wavelengths of above 630 nm); nanoclusters that emit other colors (e.g., blue or green emissions) are rare. However, Zheng and co-workers demonstrated that emission wavelength decreased with increasing number of atoms in the metallic kernel of the nanocluster.154 Therefore, ligand engineering gives us the opportunity to alter nanocluster PL properties including emitted color by changing the nanocluster size and/or configuration. Inspired by this, Kang et al. pursued the de-assembly of the assembled, red-emission bi-icosahedral nanocluster Pt2Ag23 (Fig. 4b).155 The de-assembled product was identified as Pt1Ag12, a mono-icosahedral nanocluster, with a chemical formula of Pt1Ag12(DPPM)5(SR)2 (where DPPM represents bis(diphenylphosphino)methane). 157 Such PL variation patterns further validate proposed correlations between the nanocluster size and fluorescent characteristics,154 and these three nanoclusters (Pt1Ag12, Pt2Ag23, and Pt3Ag33) were noted to constitute an ideal platform from which to further investigate the size-dependent properties in the nanocluster field.155–157
The Wu group accomplished the atomically precise transformation between non-FCC Au44(2,4-DMBT)26, FCC Au44(TBBT)28 and FCC Au43(CHT)25 nanoclusters (where, 2,4-DMBTH = 2,4- dimethylbenzenethiol, TBBTH = 4-tert-butylbenzenethiol, CHTH = cyclohexanethiol).158 Accompanied by the reversible structural transformations from FCC to non-FCC, the fluorescence of nanoclusters altered – the fluorescence of Au44(TBBT)28 was much higher than the other two nanoclusters, and the emission wavelength of Au44(TBBT)28 displayed a B20 nm red-shift relative to others. 158
Jin and co-workers resected two surface Au atoms of Au23(SR)16 and obtained the smaller nanocluster Au21(SR)12(DPPM)2 without changing the bipyramidal Au15 kernel or the two Au3(SR)4 staple motifs.159 This structural change enhanced the PL intensity by 10-fold. The enhanced emission was proposed to arise from the motif transformation-induced change of electronic interactions between the surface motifs and the Au kernel, which further led to enhanced radiative recombination of the electron–hole pair.159
Gan et al. revealed that the surface ligands and motifs have remarkable effects on fluorescence.160,161 An Au60S6(S-CH2Ph)36 nanocluster exhibited a 6H left-handed helical configuration in the crystal structure, and such an inter-cluster arrangement was proposed to explain the lower PL intensity of the Au60S6(SCH2Ph)36 nanocluster in the crystal state compared with the amorphous state.160 A heating operation introduced a single S atom onto the surface of Au60S6(S-CH2Ph)36, transforming it into the larger Au60S7(S-CH2Ph)36 nanocluster.
161 Au60S7(SCH2Ph)36 showed different crystallographic arrangements relative to its precursor, which also contributed to the contrasting PL characteristics of these two nanoclusters: the PL intensity of Au60S7(S-CH2Ph)36 in the crystal state was much higher than that in the amorphous state, whereas that of the Au60S6(S-CH2Ph)36 nanocluster was lower.161
By reacting the weakly luminescent Au25(SBB)18 (where SBB = 4-(tert butyl)benzyl mercaptan) nanocluster with Au(I)–SBB complexes at high temperature, Pradeep and co-workers obtained a highly emissive gold nanocluster, formulated as Au29(SBB)24S. 162 The red-emitting Au29 nanocluster showed an emission maximum at 737 nm with 1.8% of PL QY, in contrast to the low PL QY (0.04%) of the weakly emissive Au25SBB18 nanocluster (lem = 1030 nm). 162 The remarkable enhancement of PL was proposed to have resulted from the strengthening of the surface charge density and hence of the LMCT process via development of an additional shell on the nanocluster surface.162
Different metal nanoclusters displaying different PL characteristics can be synthesized in situ starting from different precursors (e.g., Ag(I) complexes capped with different thiolate and phosphine ligands).163–174 The Zheng group has reported a series of fluorescent Ag nanoclusters co-protected by thiolate and phosphine ligands.163,164 The selection of HSC6H3F2 and PPh3 resulted in a yellow luminescent Ag14(SC6H3F2)12(PPh3)8 nanocluster, which exhibited a strong emission at 536 nm and a minor emission at 420 nm.163 In contrast, the use of the ligands SC6H3F2 and DPPE (where DPPE = 1,2-bis(diphenylphosphino)ethane) resulted in Ag16(DPPE)4(SC6H3F2)14. Besides, the use of the ligands SC6H4CF3 and DPPE resulted in Ag32(DPPE)5(SC6H4CF3)24 as products.
164 Both Ag16 and Ag32 displayed only a prominent emission peak at 440 nm (that is, blue-emitting), which was significantly different from that of the Ag14 nanocluster.
158,159 Similarly, some alkynyl-protected, homo-silver nanoclusters have been reported;165–168 although only the Ag51( tBuCRC)32 nanocluster was found to be emissive. 165
The same choice of ligands and metal precursors can result in different metal nanoclusters with different structures and PL characteristics, depending on the synthetic procedure used.169,170 Bakr and co-workers synthesized a Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)4 nanocluster in situ by reducing the Ag(I)–SSR–PPh3 complexes with NaBH4. This homo-silver nanocluster showed a red emission at 659 nm in solution and 715 nm in the crystal state.169 By modifying the synthetic procedure used for Ag29 nanoclusters, Ghosh and co-workers obtained a Ag51(SSR)19(PPh3)3 nanocluster; which did not fluoresce under UV light.170 However, fluorescence was observed upon the addition of 2,4-DMBT ligands into the Ag51 solution. Electrospray ionization (ESI) mass spectrometry demonstrated the generation of the Ag29 nanocluster catalyzed by the introduced 2,4-DMBT ligands, and thus enhanced the PL intensity of the solution.170 Further studies reported on dictating the fluorescence of the Ag29 nanocluster.
171–175 Khatun et al. mixed the red-emissive Ag29 nanocluster, blue-emissive silicon nanoparticles, and green-emissive fluorescein isothiocyanate to obtain a cluster-based, composite nanomaterial that emitted white light.174 Very recently, Pradeep and co-workers substituted the PPh3 ligands in Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)4 with a bidentate phosphine ligand, and obtained a series of Ag29 nanoclusters with different surface configurations.175 The PL intensities of these nanoclusters were demonstrated to be directly proportional to the length of the carbon chain in bidentate phosphine ligands. Significantly, a thirty-fold PL enhancement was accomplished by replacing the PPh3 ligands on the Ag29 nanocluster surface with DPPP ligands. 175

In conclusion, ligand engineering has emerged as an effective strategy for improving the PL characteristics of atomically precise nanoclusters; and to date, most researchers have sought to influence LMCT. However, in the majority of cases, it is not possible to predict in advance the effect that a particular ligand engineering technique will have on the PL properties of a nanocluster, due to the extreme complexity of nanocluster surface environments. More studies are needed in order to improve our understanding of the relationships between ligands, nanoclusters, and PL characteristics.

sections.heading: 3 Alloying strategy for tailoring the PL of nanoclusters
sections.text:
Alloying is also a versatile strategy for tuning the performances of nanomaterials.176–188 Compared to mono-metallic nanoclusters, the physical and chemical properties (e.g. stability, catalytic, electrochemical, magnetic properties and so on) of alloyed nanoclusters are enhanced due to the complexity of the compositions and structures.189–196 The synergistic effect between different metals enables metal-composition engineering to dramatically affect the electronic and even the geometric structures of the nanoclusters, and thus can be used to tailor their properties.
Wang et al. reported a metal-exchange method for preparing alloy nanoclusters with preservation of the nanocluster template.197–200 Wu and co-workers also developed an anti-galvanic reduction (AGR) method to control the metal composition of nanoclusters.17,201–204 Such alloying methods play an increasing and critical role in dictating the chemical and physical properties of nanoclusters. Previously, the properties of alloy nanoclusters could be postsynthetically modulated by reducing different types/proportions of metal precursors. Metal-exchange and anti-galvanic strategies make it easier to accurately control the metal compositions of nanocluster kernels at the atomic level. Consequently, the detailed structure (composition)–fluorescence correlations can be obtained through precisely controlling the metallic compositions and then analyzing the PL properties of the corresponding alloy nanoclusters. Such correlations assist with the design of more alloy nanoclusters with novel metal compositions and enhanced chemical/physical properties such as fluorescence.
3.1 PL regulation via alloying with preservation of the nanocluster structure
Alloying a mono-metallic nanocluster with preservation of the nanocluster template is of great importance for it not only provides a straightforward and simple system to evaluate the alloying effect on nanocluster properties, but also sheds light on the mechanism of fluorescence of these nanoclusters.
The optical, electrochemical, and catalytic properties of atomically precise nanoclusters of the general formula M1Ag24(SR)18 (where M = Ag, Au, Pd, Pt) have been systematically characterized (Fig. 5).205–210 The homo-silver Ag25(SR)18 exhibits stronger fluorescence than its structural counterpart—Au25(SR)18; however, the PL intensity of Ag25 is still too weak to be perceived by the naked eye.205 The Bakr group reacted the Ag25(SR)18 with
a PPh3AuCl complex and obtained the Au1Ag24(SR)18 alloy nanocluster wherein a single Au heteroatom was doped into the center of the icosahedral Ag13 kernel.
206 The PL intensity increased and the emission wavelength slightly blue-shifted from 825 nm of the homo-silver Ag25(SR)18 to 805 nm of the bi-metallic Au1Ag24(SR)18 nanocluster, presumably due to the significant modulation of the HOMO–LUMO gap of the Ag25(SR)18 that took place as a result of the alloying.206 Alloying more Au heteroatoms into the Ag25(SR)18 template gave AuxAg25 x(SR)18 nanoclusters that displayed decreased PL intensity compared to Au1Ag24(SR)18, although it was still higher than that of the Ag25(SR)18.
206 In this context, the PL intensity was remarkably affected by the extent of Au doping in such AuxAg25 x(SR)18 nanoclusters. Besides, the substitution of the central Ag atom of Ag25(SR)18 with a Pd heteroatom would slightly weaken the PL intensity, whereas almost no absorption shift was observed. The maintained emission wavelength might result from the similar atomic radius between Ag and Pd.206
Liu et al. investigated the PL intensity of M1Ag24(SR)18 nanoclusters and found that the PL intensity sequences of these four homologous nanoclusters were different in the crystal or solution states: (i) in the crystal state, the PL intensity sequence was Au1Ag24 4 Pt1Ag24 4 Ag25 4 Pd1Ag24; (ii) in the solution state (acetonitrile), the PL intensity sequence was Pt1Ag24 4 Au1Ag24 4 Pd1Ag24 4 Ag25.
210 Interestingly, the PL QY of the Pt1Ag24(SR)18 nanocluster was 18.6% in acetonitrile— much higher than that for Ag25(SR)18, Pd1Ag24(SR)18 and Au1Ag24(SR)18, which were 0.6%, 0.7% and 3.5%, respectively. The solvent significantly affected the PL intensity. For instance, the QY of Pt1Ag24(SR)18 was just 0.2% in dichloromethane. 210
Regarding emission wavelength, when these nanoclusters were in the crystal state, a slight blue-shift was observed after the innermost Ag atom of Ag25(SR)18 was substituted by the introduced Pd/Pt/Au heteroatom. Specifically, the homo-silver Ag25(SR)18 emitted at 1042 nm, while emission of Au1Ag24(SR)18, Pd1Ag24(SR)18, or Pt1Ag24(SR)18 displayed a 21, 23, or 28 nm blueshift relative to that of the Ag25(SR)18 nanocluster.
210 However, the emission wavelengths of these nanoclusters were quite different in the solution state. When in acetonitrile, both Ag25(SR)18 and Au1Ag24(SR)18 nanoclusters showed a single emission at 820 nm, and Pd1Ag24(SR)18 showed a slightly red-shifted emission at 823 nm. In comparison, the Pt1Ag24(SR)18 nanocluster emitted at both 810 and 770 nm.210
In a DFT study of homo-silver Ag25(SR)18 and Au1Ag24(SR)18, the Stokes shift of the Ag25(SR)18 nanocluster was calculated as 0.37 eV and the replacement of R = H by R = PhMe2 would decrease the Stokes shift, which was in contrast to the increase in Stokes shift for aliphatic ligand stabilized Au25(SR)18 nanoclusters.211 The PL of Ag25(SR)18 originated from the HOMO– LUMO transition where core-based superatomic P and D orbitals were involved, a transition hardly affected by the doping of Au heteroatoms. Consequently, the alloying process on the Ag25(SR)18 nanocluster would not affect the mode of PL origination, but just affected the emission energies of such nanoclusters that were associated directly with the PL intensities.211

When alloying alkali metal ions into/onto the nanoclusters, three situations may occur: (i) almost no effect on the nanocluster (for most situations because of the Na-sources in NaBH4 or other added salts in synthetic procedures); (ii) cation-induced dimerization of the nanocluster (for example, Na+-induced dimerization of the Ag29(SSR)12 nanocluster);
233 (iii) metal-exchange between the alkali metals and noble-metal atoms in parent nanoclusters.234 In the last case, Zheng and co-workers pre-synthesized the Au7Ag8(CRC

Optically, the Au7Ag8 exhibited a strong emission in the near-IR region (lmax = 818 nm) with a PL QY of 2% upon excitation at l = 482 nm. However, the fluorescence was remarkably quenched in terms of the substitution of the parent Ag atoms with introduced Na+ heteroatoms (from Au7Ag8 to Na1Au7Ag7). 234
3.2 PL regulation via alloying with transformation of the nanocluster structure
Alloying may perturb the electronic and/or geometric characteristics of a nanocluster to such an extent that its structure may change, which is more likely to result in drastic changes to the physical properties of the nanocluster (such as the PL properties) compared with alloying with structure conservation. Alloying processes that change nanocluster structures in this way therefore offer the possibility of extraordinary changes in PL properties (e.g., highly boosted PL intensity or unusual emission wavelength), and are therefore highly desirable.
Tsukuda and co-workers reported the first thiol-induced self-assembly of a PPh3-stabilized Au11 mono-icosahedral nanocluster into an Au25(PPh3)10(SR)5Cl2 bi-icosahedral nanocluster. 235 The Au25(PPh3)10(SR)5Cl2 nanocluster exhibited a relatively low PL QY of 0.1% and hence was unsuitable for bio-imaging or other related applications. Aiming at solving this issue, Wang et al. combined the alloying procedure with the aforementioned thiol-induced self-assembly process, and obtained AgxAu25 x(PPh3)10(SR)5Cl2 alloy nanoclusters that strongly fluoresced (Fig. 8a).236 Specifically, the extent of Ag doping was controlled by the choice of the doping method used: (i) doping the PPh3-capped Au nanoparticles with Ag–SR generated the AgxAu25 x(PPh3)10(SR)5Cl2 (x r 12), whereas (ii) the reaction between the PPh3-stabilized Au11 nanocluster and Ag–SR complexes produced the AgxAu25 x(PPh3)10(SR)5Cl2 (x r 13).236 In this context, compared with the AgxAu25 x in route i, a special nanocluster formulated as Ag13Au12(PPh3)10(SR)5Cl2 was observed in the rod-like AgxAu25 x nanoclusters prepared by route ii. The AgxAu25 x alloy products, where x r 12, were all weakly emissive (QY B0.21%) at around
720 nm. However, the AgxAu25 x alloy nanoclusters, where x r 13, exhibited a drastically enhanced PL intensity with a QY of 40.1%, representing a 200-fold QY boost compared with x r 12 species. Besides, the emission wavelength of AgxAu25 x (x r 13) blue-shifted to 680 nm compared with the x r 12 species.236 The nanocluster responsible for the observed high fluorescence was identified as Au12Ag13(PPh3)10(SR)5Cl2, and the decisive 13th silver atom was determined to be mainly distributed at the intersection of the two icosahedral building blocks (Fig. 8a).236 Further theoretical work suggested that the origin of PL boost lay in the nature of the first excited state (S1) and its corresponding HOMO–LUMO transitions, which were significantly affected by the increasing number of Ag heteroatoms doped into the rod-like Au25 nanocluster template. 237 Ultrafast relaxation dynamics of homo-gold Au25 and silver–gold AgxAu25 x were investigated for grasping the mechanism of the PL enhancement, which demonstrated that it was the central Ag heteroatom that stabilized the charges on the LUMO orbital and enhanced the rigidity of the AgxAu25 x nanoclusters that led to strong fluorescence.238
Kang et al. accomplished the shape-transformation syntheses of alloy nanoclusters with precise atomic arrangements, and were able to compare the PL properties of these alloy nanoclusters (Fig. 8b).239 Considering the ultra-stable behavior of nanoclusters containing a Pt heteroatom in the innermost position of the icosahedral M13 kernel as well as the known metal-exchange behavior of Au and Ag on the surface of the icosahedral M13 kernel, the authors chose the Pt1Ag24(SR)18 bi-metallic nanocluster as a precursor.239 Alloying the Pt1Ag24(SR)18 with an Au–SR complex (of note, the thiol in the Au–SR complex is the same as that in the Pt1Ag24(SR)18 nanocluster) generated the tri-metallic Pt1Au6.4Ag17.6(SR)18 nanocluster, also spherical in shape. 239 Significantly, the spherical shape of Pt1Ag24 transformed into a rod-like shape after alloying with a large amount of the AuI(PPh3)Br complex. The obtained Pt2Au10Ag13(PPh3)10Br7 displayed a high PL QY (14.7%), in contrast to the weakly emissive Pt1Ag24(SR)18 nanocluster with a 150-fold enhancement.239 The emission wavelength of rod-like Pt2Au10Ag13 (648 nm) was blue-shifted compared with the bi-metallic Pt1Ag24(SR)18 at 728 nm and mono-metallic Ag25(SR)18 at 809 nm.
239 Of note, doping the Pt1Ag24(SR)18 with a small amount of the Au
I(PPh3)Cl complex resulted in Pt1AuxAg24 x(SR)18 (x = 1, 2) nanoclusters with preservation of the spherical configuration; these slightly-Audoped nanoclusters were non-emissive at room temperature, as was found for the Pt1Au6.4Ag17.6(SR)18 nanocluster. 239,240

sections.heading: 4 Aggregation-induced emission in nanoclusters
sections.text:
Aggregation-induced emission (AIE) is a photo-physical phenomenon wherein materials that are non-luminescent or weakly luminescent become highly luminescent upon aggregation either in poor solvents, or in the solid state; it is the complementary phenomenon to ACQ (aggregation-caused quenching).254,255 The Tang group was the first to propose the concept of the AIE and have reported progress in many areas of AIE research including material development, mechanism analyses, and AIEgens applications.254–263 Of note, the AIE strategy in this section actually contains two aspects: (i) AIE of nanoclusters: inducing the PL of non-luminescent metal complexes or nanoclusters; (i) AIEE (aggregation-induced emission enhancement) of nanoclusters: enhancing the PL intensity of weakly luminescent metal complexes or nanoclusters. For simplicity, these two aspects are collectively called the ‘‘AIE of nanoclusters’’ in this section.
Xie and co-workers researched the significance of AIE in the PL properties of thiolated metal nanoclusters.91 Non-luminescent oligomeric Au(I)–thiol complexes were found to generate a relatively strong emission upon aggregation induced by the addition of a poor solvent; the intensity and wavelength of the luminescence was found to depend on the degree of aggregation (Fig. 10).264 Induction of Au(I)–thiol complex aggregation onto Au(0) cores to form Au(0)@Au(I)–thiolate core–shell nanoclusters resulted in
strong luminescence generated by the AIE of Au(I)–thiol complexes on the nanocluster surface. Using this method, highly luminescent Au–SR nanoclusters with a PL QY of B15% could be prepared in a single pot.264 As shown in Fig. 10a–c, the PL intensities of these nanoclusters were in direct proportion to the degrees of aggregation that were influenced by the fe ( fe = volethanol/volethanol+water) values of the ethanol/H2O solution, which further validated the AIE mechanism. In addition, blueshift of emission wavelength occurred accompanied by the nanocluster aggregation process (Fig. 10a–c, from red-emission to yellow-emission). The aggregated nanoclusters prepared with this AIE strategy exhibited different PL emission bands from those conventionally produced due to the different lengths of the Au(I)–SR complexes (so-called staple motifs, see Fig. 10d and e). As shown in Fig. 10e, short Au(I)–SR motif are always observed on surface structures of conventional Aum(SR)n nanoclusters, whereas AIE nanoclusters are prone to be capped with long staple motifs.264 As to the mechanism of the AIE, it has been suggested that the ordered assembly of staple motifs weakens their vibration compared with their unordered states. The degree of energy dissipation by molecular vibration is therefore remarkably reduced, which in turn enhances the energy expression by radiative transition (i.e., fluorescence) of these nanoclusters.264
Self-assembly has also been accomplished by raising the temperature of nanocluster solutions.264,265 By warming a solution of Au–GSH nanoclusters to 70 1C, Luo et al. assembled them into complexes.264 A facile boiling water synthetic protocol was used to prepare luminescent Ag nanoclusters with core–shell Ag(0)@Ag(I)–SR structures.265 The high temperature-induced selfassembly arranged the Ag(I)–thiolate complexes onto the surface of an in situ synthesized Ag(0) kernel. The as-prepared assembled Ag nanoclusters featured strong PL intensity via AIE. The PL QY of such Ag nanoclusters was 7.4% with an emission peak at 686 nm.265

AIE can also aggregate the heteroatoms onto non- or weakly-luminescent mono-metallic nanoclusters to induce high luminescence.266 Specifically, the PL intensity of Au18(SG)14 was too low to be perceived by the naked eye. Introduction of Ag(I) ions to bridge and fix the small Au(I)–thiolate motifs on the weakly luminescent Au18(SG)14 surface led to the formation of larger Au(I)/Ag(0)–thiol motifs on the initial nanocluster surface. The assembled Ag(I)@Au18(SG)14 alloy nanoclusters were strongly luminescent. The emission peak of the as-synthesized Ag(I)@Au18(SG)14 nanoclusters located at 667 nm and the PL QY was about 6.8%. Of note, the addition of the cysteine could drag the binding Ag heteroatoms down from the Ag(I)@Au18(SG)14 assembled nanoclusters.266 These protocols are significant not only because they are fast (r15 minutes), scalable (Z100 mL), and general approaches for preparing the highly luminescent Au@Ag alloy nanoclusters (Ag(I)@Au15(SG)13, Ag(I)@Au18(SG)14 and Ag(I)@Au25(SG)18), but more importantly because they also exemplify the utility of AIE for the synthesis of luminescent nanomaterials.266 Li et al. reported the AIE process induced by the capture of Ag+ ions onto the Au nanocluster surface.267 Recently, Tang et al. presented the AIE of Ag nanoclusters induced by the addition of Al3+ ions.268
Polymer-induced aggregation is another efficient approach to enhance the PL intensity of non- or weak-luminescent nanoclusters.269–273 Specifically, the introduction of polyacrylic acid,269 poly(allyl amine hydrochloride),270 chitosan,271 polyvinylpyrrolidone and poly(vinyl alcohol),272 or poly(ethylene glycol) and poly(N-isopropylacrylamide)273 has been utilized for rendering the aggregation of non- or weak-luminescent, discrete metal nanoclusters, and then inducing high PL. Of note, these cluster-based AIE materials have been used in the bio-imaging field.269,270,273
Considering that the AIE primarily enhances PL by restriction of intramolecular rotation (RIR), the Zhu group designed a method to activate RIR based on an Au–Cu nanocluster.122 In their work, the active Cu complexes acted as surface ligands (like long-chain Au complexes in the AIE procedures reported by Xie et al.264), and were aggregated by the introduction of an inert Au kernel. The assembled Au–Cu nanocluster exhibited greatly improved PL intensity via activating the RIR process, and then boosting the AIE of these Cu(I)–SR complexes (Fig. 11a).122 Unlike the AIE methods mentioned above,264 this strategy did not require insoluble solutions or cations. The chemical formula of the assembled nanocluster was determined to be Au2Cu6(SAdm)6(PPh3)2. The Adm-SH ligand was then substituted by a less-rigid ligand—tert-butylmercaptan (TBM)—to obtain an Au2Cu6(TBM)6(PPh3)2 nanocluster. The PL QY of the Au2Cu6 nanoclusters was found to be proportional to the rigidity of the peripheral ligands (11.7% PL QY of the Au2Cu6–SAdm, 8.0% PL QY of the Au2Cu6–TBM). 122
The planar Au3 structure has attracted a great deal of attention due to its electron-rich nature and ability to act as a p-base to attract the acidic cations (e.g., Ag+, Tl+).274–278 Li and co-workers used tetrahydrothiophene (THT) ligands to stabilize three Au atoms into a planer Au3(THT)3 complex.
274 Aggregation of this complex to give the phosphorescent sandwich-like nanocluster
Au3(THT)3–Ag–Au3(THT)3 was accomplished by introduction of Ag + cations using solution and mechanochemical methods. The highenergy emission (355 nm) of the Au3(THT)3 complex remarkably red-shifted to the low-energy emission at 600 nm of Au3(THT)3–Ag– Au3(THT)3. 274
Due to the atomically-precise nature of nanoclusters, the chemical and physical mechanisms responsible for AIE can be identified. For example, the PL intensity of the Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)4 nanocluster in the solution state is relatively low, but greatly enhanced in the solid or crystal state. These observations suggested that aggregation significantly boosts the emission of Ag29 nanoclusters (AIE process, as shown in Fig. 11b).279 Considering that the ESI-MS spectrum of the Ag29 nanocluster showed several PPh3-free Ag29 signals (that is, Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)3, Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)2, Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)1, and Ag29(SSR)12), Kang et al. speculated that the dissociation–aggregation process of the PPh3 ligands dissipated a quantity of energy that caused the low PL intensity of Ag29 nanoclusters in the solution state. 279 The dynamic ligand dissociation–aggregation process of the Ag29 nanocluster in solution was analyzed by ESI-MS and 31P NMR measurements, and determined to be Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)4 2 Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)3 + Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)2 + Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)1 + Ag29(SSR)12 + PPh3. Accordingly, a novel AIE mechanism involving the restriction of the ‘‘dissociation–aggregation pattern’’ of PPh3 ligands was presented using the Ag29 nanocluster as a model. 279 By adding PPh3 into a solution of the Ag29 nanocluster, the PL intensity was significantly enhanced (13-times enhancement, QY from 0.9% to 11.7%) due to the restricted PPh3 dissociation– aggregation process. In contrast, the ‘‘un-dissociated’’ Pt1Ag28(SAdm)18(PPh3)4 maintained the PL intensity under the same condition of PPh3-addition. This novel mechanism was further validated in a low-temperature PL study. The temperaturedependent fluorescence exhibited two stages: (i) upon induction by the restriction of ligand dissociation–aggregation, the QY was enhanced from 0.9% to 22.5%; and (ii) upon induction by the suppression of thermal energy dissipation, QY was enhanced from 22.5% to 100%. Pt1Ag28 was found to exhibit only the stage 2 process in the temperature reducing procedure.279
The AIE phenomenon has also been observed in the Au4Ag5(DPPM)2(S-Adm)6 nanocluster.
280 The Au4Ag5 nanocluster in methanol showed gradually strengthened AIE behavior upon the addition of H2O. The PL intensity was also enhanced, when the nanocluster was in either the solid or the crystal state. A crystal structure of this nanocluster revealed that the tightly combined left- and right-handed enantiomers greatly restricted intramolecular motion (RIM), which was hypothesized to be the root cause of the AIE phenomenon.280
Crystallization-induced emission enhancement (CIEE) is a type of AIE wherein the luminescence of nanomaterials is increased upon their transition from the amorphous to the crystal state (such as solution, solid, or the film states).281–283 The Zhu group was the first to report an atomically precise nanocluster (Au4Ag13(DPPM)3(SR)9) that exhibited CIEE.
281 In the crystalline state, Au4Ag13 emitted a strong PL centered at 695 nm, but in the amorphous state, the PL was weak, and in solution, there was no PL at all. Detailed structural analyses

The aforementioned AIE works based on the atomically precise nanoclusters reported by the Xie and Zhu groups demonstrated the effect of the assembled behavior upon the ‘‘singlenanocluster events’’ rather than the ‘‘nanocluster–nanocluster aggregation.117,258,266 Indeed, the nanocluster–nanocluster aggregation has been observed to induce PL intensity boost and emission switching.284–287
Wu et al. induced the rapid aggregation of Cu nanoclusters into ultrathin Cu-based nanosheets with ethanol.286 The resulting self-assembly promoted the formation of a metal defect-rich surface on the nanosheet. XPS (X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy)
results demonstrated the increased Cu(I)-to-Cu(0) ratio in the nanosheet relative to that in the non-aggregated samples. In addition, DFT calculations suggested that such an increase influenced the ligand-to-metal–metal charge transfer (LMMCT) process, and thereby facilitated the radiative relaxation of excitons. Accordingly, the cluster-assembled nanosheets exhibited obvious emission red-shift (from 400 to 550 nm) and enhancement (15.4% of the PL QY in the nanosheet state). Furthermore, the as-prepared Cu nanosheets showed a temperature-dependent emission variation from 550 nm at 298 K to 517 nm at 77 K, accompanied by the remarkable enhancement in terms of the PL intensity.286
The Konishi group reported the aggregation-induced fluorescence-to-phosphorescence switching based on the Au8 nanocluster.287 In good solvents, the Au8 nanocluster existed as a monomer owing to its highly soluble behavior, and displayed a single PL peak at 600 nm at ambient temperatures. sections.heading: 5 Nanocluster-based networks
sections.text:
Due to their maneuverable surface coordination chemistry, noble metal nanoclusters can be controllably connected into cluster-based networks through interactions between the nanoclusters with specific linkers. Such cluster-based networks show distinctive PL characteristics compared with the nanocluster building blocks (or nanocluster monomers) due to the (i) complex, three-dimensional architectures, (ii) diverse interactions between nanoclusters and linkers, and (iii) cluster assembly-induced porosity of these networks, which are reminiscent of the characteristics of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs).288–294 The porosity of cluster-based networks enables their use for the specific identification of solvents or gas molecules through analysis of the specific PL responses (e.g., the variations in emissive intensity or wavelength) induced by the addition of these molecules. Whereas the aggregation method (AIE) may change the composition and configuration of the initial compounds, cluster-based networks reflect an aggregation of nanoclusters induced by the addition of linkers, where nanocluster composition and configuration are almost unchanged.
Recently, Zang and co-workers demonstrated that the interactions between nanoclusters and functional linkers enabled silver nanocluster building blocks to self-assemble into clusterbased networks that exhibited different PL characteristics compared to the nanocluster monomers (Fig. 12).295–301 Such cluster-based networks not only enrich the nanocluster family, but also fill the gap between nanoclusters and MOFs.295–301 The interaction between the Ag kernel and CH3CN moiety (through Ag–N bonds) was observed in a dodecanuclear Ag12(S
tBu)6(CF3COO)6(CH3CN)6 (Ag12–CH3CN for short) nanocluster; however, its low PL intensity and instability have hampered more extensive studies of this nanocluster.295 To solve this problem, the Ag12– CH3CN nanocluster was grafted with adaptable bridging ligands (4,40-bipyridine in this work, BPY for short), enabling their inter-connection and the formation of rigid cluster-based networks (Ag12(S tBu)8(CF3COO)4(BPY)4, Ag12–bpy-1 for short). 295 The assembled Ag12–BPY network exhibited a 60-fold enhanced
PL QY (12.1%, with a 520 nm emission) as well as high stability (over one year), in contrast to the low PL QY (0.2%, with a 507 nm emission) and poor stability (decomposed within 30 minutes) of the unassembled Ag12–CH3CN building blocks (Fig. 12a, left).295 Because of the porous structure of this welldefined nanocluster-based network, ultrafast dual-function fluorescence switching (within 1 s) was achieved, with emission turn-off triggered by O2, and multi-color-emission turn-on by volatile organic compounds (Fig. 12a, right). The emission switching mechanism was theoretically elucidated by DFT-calculating the specifically occupied positions of the small molecules within the clusterbased network, based on the atomically precise single-crystal-tosingle-crystal transformation models.295
Huang et al. obtained another Ag12-based network Ag12(StBu)6(CF3COO)6(BPY)3 (Ag12–BPY-2 for short) by changing the number of both capped ligands and BPY linkers in the Ag12–BPY1 network (Fig. 12b).296 The nanocluster isomer transformation tailored the PL of the nanocluster-based network from 520 nm of single-emissive Ag12–BPY-1 to 463 and 620 nm of dual-emissive Ag12–BPY-2. A temperature dependence of the PL intensity was also noted—the lower the temperature, the stronger the PL intensity.296 Furthermore, the use of mixed BPY and BPY-NH2 linkers constructed an Ag12 nanocluster-network crystal with thermochromic properties. Based on the crystals of Ag12–BPY-2@ Ag12–BPY-2-NH2, reversible PL transformation between blue and purple emissions was directly perceived, accompanied by a temperature conversion between 293 K and 83 K, respectively (Fig. 12b).296
By substituting the linear BPY linker into the star-like tridentate TPPA linker (where TPPA = tris(4-pyridylphenyl)-amine), Du et al. assembled the Ag12 building blocks into the porous Ag12–TPPA cluster-based networks, and further investigated the PL characteristics of these networks.297 Due to interactions between the porous structures and guest dimethylacetamide (DMAc) molecules, wherein the guest DMAc was partially removed from the as-prepared crystals, the mono-layered Ag12–TPPA-AA (inter-layer distance: 11.17 Å) transformed into two thermodynamically favored structures—bi-layered Ag12–TPPA-AB (inter-layer distance: 7.49 Å) and tri-layered Ag12–TPPA-ABC (inter-layer distance: 3.90 Å).297 Because these three nanocluster assembled modes showed different structures, a red-shifted PL emission was observed from the mono-layered Ag12–TPPA-AA (475 nm) to the multi-layered Ag12–TPPA-AB or Ag12–TPPA-ABC (545 nm) network. 297
Pyridine functionalized linkers have also been used to generate Ag10 and Ag14 cluster-based networks.
299,300 By using the 2-dithiolateo-carborane ligand and bidentate N-containing linkers, Wang et al. obtained a Ag14 cluster-based network.
299 Besides, the Ag10 clusterbased network was synthesized by the use of StBu and CF3COO ligands as well as BPY linkers.300 Owing to the porous structures of these nanocluster-based networks and the specific interactions between the framework channels and some gas or solvent molecules, such nanocluster networks displayed intriguing temperature- and solvent-dependent PL properties, such as low temperature-induced PL enhancements as well as emission transformations (Fig. 12c).299,300
Indeed, the inter-nanocluster linking strategy has exhibited unique superiority in structural engineering and property tailoring.

sections.heading: 6 Other methods for tailoring the PL of nanoclusters
6.1 Rigidification by surface shell engineering
sections.text:
Water-soluble nanoclusters have attracted increasing interest due to their intriguing chemical–physical properties (e.g., photo-stability and high luminescence) and biological applications.70–75,302–304 However, because of the complexity of the water-soluble ligands, the PL of these hydrophilic nanoclusters is difficult to be controlled precisely. In these years, surface shell rigidification has been fully investigated for tailoring the PL performances of these hydrophilic nanoclusters.
First of all, the introduction of bulky counter-ions is able to rigidify the surface shell of nanoclusters. It was hoped that the compact packing of the introduced counter-ions onto the nanocluster surface would rigidify the metal–thiol shell and decrease the energy loss among intramolecular rotations and vibrations, and then increase the PL intensity of these packed nanoclusters. Yu et al. reported the synthesis and PL properties of the Au22(SG)18 (where SG = glutathione) nanocluster. Au22(SG)18 luminesced intensely at B665 nm with a high PL QY of B8%, which was relatively higher than those of other SG capped gold nanoclusters.304 Subsequently, Lee and co-workers introduced the bulky tetraoctylammonium (TOA+) cations into the aqueous solution of the Au22(SG)18 nanocluster, which transferred the nanocluster from the aqueous to the toluene phase due to the ion-pairing effect (Fig. 13a) and increased the PL QY of the Au22 nanocluster from 8.0% (water) to 460% (toluene).305 The PL intensity of the assembled Au22(SG)18 nanocluster could be finely tuned via control of the phase-transfer agents and the resulting PL intensity was directly proportional to the chain length of the introduced phase-transfer agents (Fig. 13a).305
In another work, the fluorescence of the Au22(SG)18 nanocluster was tuned through rigidification of the Au(I) thiolate shell by covalently modifying it using small aromatic molecules and pyrene chromophores.306 A five-fold enhancement of PL (30% of PL QY) was observed. In addition, ion-pairing of the
modified Au22 with TOA + cations further enhanced the PL QY, which led to a dramatic 37-fold enhancement of PL intensity.306 Zhang and co-workers reported the PL enhancement through a TOA+/toluene phase-transfer process based on a small-size Au10(SG)10 nanocluster (Fig. 13b).
307 Based on the atomically precise crystal structure of the Pt1Ag28(SSR)12(PPh3)4 nanocluster, Bootharaju et al. performed DFT calculations to investigate the ion pairing effect, and predicted the mechanism that induced the PL enhancement at the atomic level (Fig. 13c).308,309 The Xie group proposed this ion-pairing method as a scalable strategy for synthesizing highly fluorescent Ag, Au, Pt, and Cu nanoclusters on a large scale.310 Phase transfer cycle procedures were developed to process poly-dispersed, non-fluorescent, and unstable Ag nanoclusters into mono-dispersed, highly fluorescent, and ultra-stable Ag nanoclusters in the same phase (aqueous) and capped with the remaining ligands. Highly fluorescent and ultrastable Au, Pt, and Cu nanoclusters have also been prepared by this strategy.310
Introducing zwitterionic ligands to cap the metallic kernel is another efficient approach to rigidify the surface structure of metal nanoclusters. Of note, GSH or proteins possess zwitterionic structures and, when coated on the nanocluster surface, are able to prevent the intramolecular rotations and vibrations of nanocluster surface structures. To date, several GSH or protein (mainly BSA) protected, highly luminescent nanoclusters have been reported.103,106–109,304,307,311–321 Besides, by using the bidentate thiol zwitterionic ligand, the Mattoussi and the Guével groups have prepared several fluorescent nanoclusters.216,322–327 The PL intensity and emission wavelength of these nanoclusters can be easily tailored via controlling the functional groups on the zwitterionic ligands.323,324,327

The energy dissipation of photo-excited nanoclusters takes place through two pathways: (i) non-radiative transitions (mainly affected by intra-nanocluster vibrations), and (ii) radiative transitions (through fluorescence). Since the nanoclusters in excited states must release energy to reach the ground-state energy, the suppression of thermal energy dissipation (or the restriction of intramolecular motions) should in turn increase the radiative transitions of nanoclusters.279 Consequently, the PL intensity of nanoclusters should be enhanced along with the reduction of atmospheric temperature, and non-radiative transitions would remarkably decrease.279
Temperature can influence the PL of nanoclusters (Fig. 14a). The temperature-dependent fluorescence of the dissociative Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)4 cluster shows three stages: (i) when the temperature was reduced from 293 K to 251 K, the PL QY of Ag29 increased from 0.9% to 22.5%, a 25-fold enhancement; (ii) further cooling from 251 K to 107 K increased the PL QY of Ag29 from 22.5% to almost 100%; (iii) the PL QY of Ag29 was maintained at 100% when the temperature was reduced below 107 K.279 In contrast, the non-dissociative Pt1Ag28(S-Adm)18(PPh3)4 nanocluster exhibited only one stage of PL change—a 20-fold enhancement of the PL intensity and 1.9-fold enhancement of the UV-vis absorption upon cooling from 293 K to 125 K. Thus, the PL QY of the Pt1Ag28 nanocluster at low temperature (lower than 125 K)
was also 100%.279 It was suggested that stage 1 of the Ag29 PL enhancement was caused by the restriction of the ‘‘ligand dissociation–aggregation pattern’’, which promoted AIE; and stage 2 of the Ag29 nanocluster or the only state of the Pt1Ag28 nanocluster was completely induced by the suppression of thermal energy dissipation.279
Nanoclusters may show different PL performance (emissions and lifetimes) at different temperatures.297 At low temperatures, Ag12–TPPA-AA (see the synthesis in Section 5) exhibited long afterglow for seconds that could be detectable by the naked eye. For example, at 83 K, the lifetime at high-energy (with a 465 nm emission) was calculated as 1.63 ns, while the phosphorescence lifetime at low-energy (with 525 and 560 nm emissions) was 0.16 s.297

sections.heading: 6.3 Solvent-dependent PL of nanoclusters
sections.text:
Solvents can also influence nanocluster PL properties, although to a lesser degree than that seen in metal complexes. For example, poorly soluble nanoclusters are prone to aggregate, which can remarkably enhance their PL intensities.91,264 In addition, specific interactions between the channels in cluster-based networks and the introduced solvent molecules make such frameworks with differently visible PL colors.247,295
Zhou et al. evaluated the solvent dependence of PL of the Au6Ag2–C nanocluster.
341 The PL intensity of this nanocluster in CH2Cl2 was much stronger than that in CH3CN or CH3OH. By varying the solvent polarity and hydrogen bonding ability, the relative populations of the triplet MLCT (metal-to-ligand charge transfer) states and the emission properties of the nanocluster could be moderated.341 It was found that in CH3OH, an additional site-specific O–H p was formed with the aromatic rings of the nanocluster ligands, which enhanced the ultrafast non-radiative decay of the hydrogen bond stabilized 3MLCTAu state and reduced the population of the emissive 3MLCTAg state. Consequently, the PL intensity of Au6Ag2–C in CH3OH was weaker, relative to that in other solvents.
341 The PL intensities of M1Ag24(SR)18 nanoclusters are also found to be significantly impacted by the solvent.210 For example, the PL intensity of Ag25, Pd1Ag24 and Pt1Ag24 in acetonitrile was much brighter than that in toluene, dichloromethane, acetone and dimethyl sulfoxide; however, the PL intensity of Au1Ag24 in dichloromethane was higher than that in other solvents. In addition, the sequences of the PL intensity of these four homologous nanoclusters were different when in the crystal or solution state, which was probably due to the different emission mechanisms and nanocluster–atmosphere interactions of these nanoclusters when in the different states.210

sections.heading: 6.4 Fluorescence resonance energy transfer in nanoclusters
sections.text:
Fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) has served as a powerful technique for enhancing the PL of nanoclusters, mainly by absorbing efficiently the excited light with donors and then transferring the energy to the metallic core of the acceptor nanoclusters.342–351 Ligand-conjugation is the most efficient and convenient approach for anchoring donors onto the nanocluster surface.342–351
The Pradeep and the Pal groups carried out a series of studies on FRET.342–346 Based on the glutathione protected
Au25 nanocluster, they incorporated the dansyl chromophores on the nanocluster surface via the amidation between dansyl groups and glutathione ligands.342 The emission of Au25(SG)18 (585 nm, with an excitation of 535 nm) overlaps the emission of the dansyl group, demonstrating the possibility of FRET. Efficient energy transfer from the dansyl donor to the Au25 acceptor was manifested by a systematic quenching of donor’s emission and increase in emission of Au25(SG)18.
342 Lactoferrin, porphyrin, graphene, and nanoparticles have also served as donors for inducing the FRET and then enhancing the PL intensity of nanocluster acceptors.343–346 Liu et al. reported the FRET between the blue-emission polyhedral oligomeric silsesquioxane and red-emission Au nanoclusters.347 Raut and co-workers presented the evidence of energy transfer from tryptophan/pacific blue to BSA/HSA protected Au nanoclusters.348,349 Recently, the concept of FRET has been exploited in carbon nanotube–nanocluster or carbon dot–nanocluster systems, and rendered weak-luminescent nanoclusters strongly luminescent.350,351

sections.heading: 6.5 Special approaches to control the PL of nanoclusters
sections.text:
Several other factors can affect the fluorescent characteristics of nanoclusters. Waszkielewicz et al. reported the pH-induced size-transformation from Au25(Capt)18 to a brighter Au23(Capt)17 nanocluster; the PL intensity of the Au23(Capt)17 nanocluster at pH = 2 displayed a 12-fold enhancement compared to that of the Au25(Capt)18 at pH = 7.
352 Water-soluble nanoclusters are prone to pH-dependent fluorescence due to the hydrophilic nature of their ligands (e.g., GSH, Capt).352 Wang and co-workers synthesized stable Cu nanoclusters, which could serve as pH stimuliresponsive functional materials.353 Such nanoclusters were highly emissive at pH = 3.1, however non-emissive at pH = 7.1.353
Wu and Jin increased the electro-positivity of the Au25 metallic kernel of Au25(SC2H4Ph)18 by decreasing the free electron count of the nanocluster, further promoting LMCT and enhancing the PL intensity of the nanocluster.103 Specifically, the [Au25(SC2H4Ph)18]
2+ with 5 free electrons shows a 10-fold enhancement of PL intensity compared with [Au25(S-C2H4Ph)18]
with 8 free electrons.103 Wang et al. observed a similar PL-variation tendency in the Au25(NAPS)18 nanocluster. 105
Nag et al. presented the polymorphism-dependent PL intensity based on the Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)4 nanocluster with cubic or trigonal configurations in different single crystals.354 The C–H p interactions of the PPh3 ligands of the Ag29(SSR)12(PPh3)4 nanocluster were stronger in the cubic lattice than in the trigonal one, resulting in a greater rigidity of the cubic configuration, which in turn, gave rise to a higher PL efficiency (Fig. 14c).354
Nanocluster structural isomers differ in their configurations, and thus may display different PL characteristics. Kang et al. obtained a Pt1Ag28(S-Adm)18(PPh3)4 (Pt1Ag28-1) nanocluster by ligand-exchanging the Pt1Ag24(S-PhMe2)18 with HS-Adm and PPh3 ligands.
153 Lin et al. reported an in situ synthetic method to prepare the Pt1Ag28(S-Adm)18(PPh3)4 (Pt1Ag28-2) nanocluster, by directly reducing the Ag–SR–PPh3 complexes.
