sections.heading: 7 Applications of fluorescent nanoclusters
sections.text:
Compared with the conventional fluorophores such as organic fluorophores, semiconductor QDs, or fluorescent proteins, fluorescent nanoclusters exhibit an appealing set of unprecedented features. For example, although organic fluorophores are present in a wide range of chemical compounds, they are prone to photobleaching.77 Semiconductor QDs are fluorescence-tunable and exhibit good photo-stability; however, their relatively large molecular sizes hinder their applications.81–84,356,357 Fluorescent proteins are genetically editable, which can be generated by the cells/organisms themselves.358–361 Consequently, there is little need for the chemical procedures in studies of live cells and organisms. However, fluorescent nanoclusters show strong PL intensity, good photo-stability, wide emission wavelengths, and exhibit ultra-small sizes and atomically precise structures, which establish them as a new class of fluorophores for applications in chemical sensing and biological fields.64–75
It should be noted that our intention in this review is to highlight the advances in tailoring the PL performances of metal nanoclusters. Besides, in the past few years, several related overviews have been published focusing on the sensing or biological applications of the fluorescent nanoclusters (mainly hydrophilic nanoclusters).4,64,65,67–74 Consequently, this section just gives a brief introduction on applications of fluorescent nanoclusters. Only some recent works based on fluorescent nanoclusters are highlighted in detail.

sections.heading: 7.1 Chemical sensing
sections.text:
Fluorescent nanoclusters for chemical sensing are of great interest owing to their simplicity, sensitivity, and specificity. Efficient detection of Hg2+ ions is central to the environmental monitoring of aquatic ecosystems due to their deleterious effects on the environment and human health. Using the highly fluorescent BSA-stabilized Au25 nanoclusters, Xie et al. presented an ultrasensitive method for the detection of Hg2+ ions in the aqueous phase.362 Specifically, high-affinity metallophilic Hg2+–Au+ interactions effectively quenched the fluorescence of BSA–Au25 nanoclusters, but other metal ions (e.g., Ag+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Fe3+, et al.) hardly affected the PL performance of BSA–Au25 nanoclusters.362 Other fluorescent Au or Ag nanoclusters stabilized by different ligands were also used to detect the Hg2+ ions in the aqueous phase.363–367 Although the precise structure determination of these hydrophilic nanoclusters has some differences compared with the hydrophobic ones because of the ligand effects, their general structures are similar (e.g., hydrophilic Au18(SG)14 and hydrophobic Au18(SR)14).
368 Consequently, compared with the nanoparticle sensors, the atomically precise structures of these nanocluster sensors make it possible to elucidate the mechanism
of the ion detections (or the PL variations). Aside from Hg2+, fluorescent nanoclusters have always been used to detect other ions, including Cu2+ ions,369–372 As3+ ions,373 S2 ions,374,375 NO2 ,376 CN ,377 and so on. Very recently, the highly fluorescent Ag29(SSR)12(DPPP)4 ligand was developed to be a prototypical O2 sensor,175 wherein the PL intensity of Ag29 nanoclusters was gradually decreased by O2 purging. Further purging by N2, CO2 or Ar helped in the removal of the dissolved O2 from the Ag29 solution, and restoring the PL intensity.175
Fluorescent nanoclusters have also been used to detect proteins in solution.378,379 Martinez and co-workers synthesized an intrinsically fluorescent recognition ligand and used it to stabilize Ag nanoclusters.378 Such Ag nanoclusters showed high fluorescence (PL QY more than 50%) when they met the target proteins. This work presented a versatile method to detect specific proteins by anchoring DNA aptamers with a strong binding affinity for proteins on the nanocluster surface.378 Yuan et al. synthesized a fluorescent Ag nanocluster stabilized by the GSH ligands, the emission of which was quenched in the presence of cysteine. In this context, these Ag nanoclusters could be used as a highly selective and sensitive cysteine sensor.379

sections.heading: 7.2 Biological applications
sections.text:
Fluorescent nanoclusters have several advantages over organic fluorophores or semiconductor QDs for biological applications, including: (i) nontoxicity, owing to the reduced state of the metals present; (ii) ultra-small size compared with semiconductor QDs, which eases their entry into cells, (iii) high biocompatibility; (iv) strong photo-stability compared with fluorophores, (v) strong luminescence; (vi) potential anti-cancer activity; and (vii) amenability to further functionalization, due to the presence of modifiable ligands on the nanocluster surface.64–74 Several biological applications of fluorescent nanoclusters have been reported.64–74
The Dickson group developed a versatile method to synthesise and stabilize a series of small-sized, DNA-templated, homosilver nanoclusters.311–319 Such Ag nanoclusters are able to emit in a wide range between 450 and 700 nm, and have been used for sensing and biolabeling applications that would benefit from these brighter and more photo-stable nanoclusters in high background environments (Fig. 15a, top).311–316 Yu et al. demonstrated that these DNA-encapsulated Ag nanoclusters could serve as alternatives to organic dyes and semiconductor QDs due to their high luminescence and good photostability at the molecular level, when used to stain live cell surfaces.317 Upon photoactivation, small Ag nanoclusters (2–7 Ag atoms) formed and were used to stain the cells at ambient temperature.318 The staining images emphasized several bright regions reminiscent of nucleoli of the cell, on top of weak cytoplasmic and nuclear emission.318 Of note, the emission intensity of the bright regions induced by the existence of Ag nanoclusters was twice the intensity of that from the cytoplasm, and displayed broad emission between 500–700 nm.318 In follow-up work, ssDNAencapsulated Ag nanoclusters (where ssDNA = single-stranded DNA) were prepared by a ‘‘nanocluster shuttle’’ method.319 Specifically, the small Ag nanoclusters were first prepared and further anchored by the ssDNA scaffolds. sections.heading: 7.3 Other applications
sections.text:
Owing to their ultra-small sizes, discrete electronic states, and modifiable surfaces, fluorescent nanoclusters have been used in some special applications. Shang et al. synthesized a series of fluorescent gold nanoclusters with high intensity and excellent photo-stability, over the physiological temperature range.386 In addition, these nanoclusters exhibited temperature-sensitive fluorescence lifetimes, and were therefore posited to be useful for intracellular thermometry.386
Very recently, Lee and co-workers modified the surface of Au22(SG)18 with the pH-responsive dye aminofluorescein (AF); the resulting Au22–AF nanocluster functioned as a highly sensitive pH probe (Fig. 16a).127 Steady-state PL measurements showed that, when conjugated to an Au22(SG)18 nanocluster, the fluorescein nanocluster displayed a more than 160-fold pH-contrasting PL in the pH range of 4.3–7.8. Transient absorption measurements suggested that there were two competing ultrafast processes in such Au22–AF nanoclusters: (i) the intracore-state relaxation and (ii) the energy transfer from the non-thermalized states of the Au22 kernel to the anchored fluorescein. The latter process was observed to predominate at higher pH, leading to a more efficient energy transfer and a dramatic PL enhancement of the fluorescein. In this context, a sensitive pH probe was prepared.127
The Yang group showed that the highly fluorescent gold nanocluster Au22(SG)18 could serve as an intercellular photosensitizer to enable the non-photosynthetic bacterium M. thermoacetica to achieve efficient photosynthesis.387 As shown in Fig. 16b, the small, highly biocompatible Au22(SG)18 nanocluster was introduced into the bacterium, whereupon the bacterium gained the ability to catalyze the conversion of CO2 into acetic acid.387 It was found that the intracellular Au22(SR)18
nanocluster could photo-generate electrons under optical excitation, which could be passed to cytoplasmic mediators by the Wood– Ljungdhal pathway, bypassing the slow mass transport and energy consumption across the cell membrane. Significantly, the gold nanocluster also inhibited reactive oxygen species, to maintain high bacterium viability. Overall, the constructed, artificially photosynthetic biohybrid system was capable of efficiently harvesting sunlight and transferring the photo-generated electrons to cellular metabolism, which realized CO2 fixation continuously over several days.387

sections.heading: 8 Conclusion and perspective
sections.text:
In this review, we summarized recent advances in the tailoring of the fluorescence (including the PL intensity and emission wavelength) of atomically precise nanoclusters, by (1) engineering the peripheral ligands on the nanocluster surface; (2) modifying the kernel size or alloying the kernel with hetero-metals; (3) exploiting AIE; (4) self-assembling the nanocluster building blocks into cluster-based networks; and (5) regulating the ambient conditions such as temperatures and solvents. Through these advances, and an improved understanding of the PL mechanism, it is anticipated that the fluorescent nanocluster will emerge as a promising new member in the class of fluorophores and impact the fields of chemical sensing, bio-imaging, bio-labeling, etc.
However, much work remains to be done. The PL performance of most current nanoclusters is still unsatisfactory: PL QYs are generally lower than 20%; emission wavelengths are generally above 630 nm; and emission lifetimes are in the nanosecond range. Accordingly, although remarkable progress in the tuning of nanocluster PL characteristics has been made, there remains significant room for improvement. Also, a complete understanding of the key features of fluorescent nanocluster PL regulation remains elusive; in particular, most current explanations regarding the mechanisms of nanocluster fluorescence and how factors such as ligand chemistry, core size, metal composition, temperature,

A comprehensive mechanistic understanding of the origins of PL is needed, to shift our ability to control nanocluster PL characteristics from empirically-driven guesswork to a highly predictable science. In addition, a thorough understanding of the PL mechanism requires more fluorescent nanoclusters with precise structures, which enable us to elucidate structure–PL correlations at the atomic level.
Other important areas of nanocluster research are the regulation of LMCT or LMMCT via precise control of the electronwithdrawing capability of metallic kernels and the electron-donating capability of capped ligands; deepening our understanding of the nanocluster AIE process; developing novel linkers that induce the self-assembly of the nanocluster building blocks (especially towards a controllable channel size); and evaluating the detailed effects of the external environments on the PL properties of nanoclusters to excavate the optimal conditions for preparing nanoclusters with desirable PL characteristics.
To date, several atomically-precise hydrophobic nanoclusters (e.g., Au24, rod-like AuAg25, and Au1Ag24) have been reported with high PL intensities; however, their hydrophobic nature has impeded their application in chemical sensing, bio-imaging, bio-labeling, biotherapy and so on. Hydrophilic PL nanoclusters are much better suited for biological applications, due to their (i) non-toxicity, (ii) small size, (iii) ability to easily enter cells, (iv) good biocompatibility, (v) good photo-stability, (vi) strong luminescence, (vii) potential anti-cancer activity, and (viii) ability to bear functional ligands, for the purposes of drug delivery.64–75 Drawbacks of known hydrophilic nanoclusters include (i) PL properties that are more difficult to control than those of the hydrophobic nanoclusters, and (ii) atomically imprecise structures that preclude quantitative tracking in organisms. These drawbacks greatly limit the practical uses of hydrophilic nanoclusters in biological applications. In this context, methods to transfer atomically precise, highly fluorescent, hydrophobic nanoclusters into water, and then use them for biological applications, should be an important goal in this field.
Although there have been several studies on the optical imaging techniques of metal nanoclusters as fluorescent probes in vitro and in vivo, most of them concern one-photon excitation properties. On the other hand, there are only few reports in which nanoclusters have been successfully applied as fluorophores for in vitro two-photon (or multi-photon) imaging.388–391 Two-photon (or multi-photon) luminescence microscopy has many advantages over one-photon optical microscopy such as high-resolution imaging even at a deep cellular level, localized red or infrared excitation in a small focal volume, and reduced photo-toxicity and photo-bleaching.388–392 Recently, several approaches have been presented that are able to tailor the two-photon excited fluorescence of metal nanoclusters, such as kernel-size engineering,393,394 ligandengineering,395 alloying,396 and shell-rigidification strategies.321,397 Of note, the research of multi-photon excitation microscopy in nanoclusters is still in its infancy, and further development of this field calls for more efforts.
Finally, we believe that research into nanocluster PL engineering can lead to novel, smart nanomaterials that offer solutions to
problems related to the environment, biology, and human health.

metadata.abstractText: Due to their atomically precise structures and intriguing chemical/physical properties, metal nanoclusters are an emerging class of modular nanomaterials. Photo-luminescence (PL) is one of their most fascinating properties, due to the plethora of promising PL-based applications, such as chemical sensing, bio-imaging, cell labeling, phototherapy, drug delivery, and so on. However, the PL of most current nanoclusters is still unsatisfactory—the PL quantum yield (QY) is relatively low (generally lower than 20%), the emission lifetimes are generally in the nanosecond range, and the emitted color is always red (emission wavelengths of above 630 nm). To address these shortcomings, several strategies have been adopted, and are reviewed herein: capped-ligand engineering, metallic kernel alloying, aggregation-induced emission, self-assembly of nanocluster building blocks into cluster-based networks, and adjustments on external environment factors. We further review promising applications of these fluorescent nanoclusters, with particular focus on their potential to impact the fields of chemical sensing, bio-imaging, and bio-labeling. Finally, scope for improvements and future perspectives of these novel nanomaterials are highlighted as well. Our intended audience is the broader scientific community interested in the fluorescence of metal nanoclusters, and our review hopefully opens up new horizons for these scientists to manipulate PL properties of nanoclusters. This review is based on publications available up to December 2018.
